Cryptography Q1: Digitally signing files and messages to authenticate senders
Cryptography Q2: Uses one key to encrypt blocks of text to be ciphered and another key to decrypt it back
Cryptography Q3: Hashing is one-way cryptography in that you transform a meaningful plaintext into a meaningless but unique hash value but you cannot go from hash value back to the original meaning or plaintext
Cryptography Q4: The certificate public key or both associated with the sender or author match what is associated with the file or message
Cryptography Q5: The sender hashes the message or file to produce a message digest and applies the chosen decryption algorithm and their private key to it. This is the signature. The recipient uses the sender's public key and applies the corresponding encryption algorithm to the signature which will produce a matching message digest only if the message or file is authentically from the sender
Cryptography Q6: Governments implement cryptographic module verifications programs which assure businesses that systems they use that contain such modules will meet regulatory and legal constraints for privacy data protection and product safety
Cryptography Q7: No matter what kind of cryptanalytic attack the larger the key the larger the possible space of key values that an attacker must test; each additional binary bit doubles this search or testing time. Ultimately this requires more computing power and storage than even the most well-funded governments can afford
Cryptography Q8: No because a hash is a many-to-one function and thus must have a collision detection and avoidance mechanism as part of its implementation; being reversible would negate this
Cryptography Q9: Since much of the Internet is carried on long-haul backbone circuits that go via satellite encryption is used to protect data while being transmitted via radio through space to and from the satellite and ground stations. Without encryption anybody could receive these signals and break out the data being exchangedDespite traveling at the speed of light Internet traffic takes time to go from one user's system to another (i.e. from a client to a server); thus encryption protects the data in motion during this time
Cryptography Q10: Cryptography cannot be used to reduce risks to information availability
BCDR Q2: RTO should be less than or equal to MAO
BCDR Q4: Plans represent significant investments and decisions and thus should be updated only when significant changes to objectives or circumstances dictate
BCDR Q7: We cannont run the risk that whatever caused the attack isn't dormant in your systems and that it wouldn't spread to our other systems or back out onto the Internet if we did thatYours are not the only systems affected by this attack; we've had to shut down most of our IT operations to make sure that our critical data and systems are protected
BCDR Q8: Indicators are events that are part of an information security incident kill chain; warnings are observable effects that we can detect that tell us of the occurrences of the indicator
BCDR Q9: Containment and eradication are separate and distinct tasks; once containment is complete the incident response team moves on to eradications of the causal agent(s)
BCDR Q10: Anomalies in applications behavior

Cryptography Q1: Obscuring meaning by misdirection concealment or deception
Cryptography Q2: Uses the same key or a simple transform of it to encrypt plaintext into ciphertext and to then decrypt the ciphertext back into plaintext
Cryptography Q3: Hashing is one-way cryptography in that you transform a meaningful plaintext into a meaningless but unique hash value but you cannot go from hash value back to the original meaning or plaintext
Cryptography Q4: The certificate public key or both associated with the sender or author match what is associated with the file or message
Cryptography Q5: The sender hashes the message or file to produce a message digest and applies the chosen encryption algorithm and their private key to it. This is the signature. The recipient uses sender's public key and applies the corresponding decryption algorithm to the signature which will produce a matching message digest only if the message or file is authentically from the sender
Cryptography Q6: Governments implement cryptographic module verifications programs which assure businesses that systems they use that contain such modules will meet regulatory and legal constraints for privacy data protection and product safety
Cryptography Q7: No matter what kind of cryptanalytic attack the larger the key the larger the possible space of key values that an attacker must test; each additional binary bit doubles this search or testing time. Ultimately this requires more computing power and storage than even the most well-funded governments can afford
Cryptography Q8: In a limited way they are reversible because the hash acts as a pointer or key into database and file management systems where the plaintext comes from
Cryptography Q9: Since much of the Internet is carried on long-haul backbone circuits that go via satellite encryption is used to protect data while being transmitted via radio through space to and from the satellite and ground stations. Without encryption anybody could receive these signals and break out the data being exchangedEncrypting a file for storage ensures that it cannot be read or tampered with by unauthorized users or processes (which do not have the key); later authorized users with the key can read the file
Cryptography Q10: Display of data to humans or output of data as device commands in control systems needs to be in an unecrypted for to be usableEven cryptographic support for nonrepudiation cannot prove that a recipient (authorized of not) actually read and understood or made use of the contents of a protected file or message; it can only prove that they accessed it
BCDR Q2: RTO should be less than or equal to MAO
BCDR Q4: Plans represent significant investments and decisions and thus should be updated only when significant changes to objectives or circumstances dictate
BCDR Q7: We could assume that your systems were not contaminated by the attack and let you run on them. We'd take them down and inspect them later when you're not using themWe have to comply with our policies that tell us how to handle incidents like this and so we can't do that
BCDR Q8: Indicators are the observable signals from an event which may suggest that an information systems security event may happen later
BCDR Q9: Containment primarily addresses shutting down connectivity between networks subnets systems and servers. Eradication addresses locating the causal agents (malware bogus user IDs etc.) and removing them from each system
BCDR Q10: Recurrent problems with data corruption in database entries

Cryptography Q1: Obscuring meaning by making it difficult or impossible for unauthorized users to access view copy or change it
Cryptography Q2: Was used extensively in classical encryption but has since been superseded by much stronger asymmetric encryption
Cryptography Q3: Hashing the contents of a file or message is the first step in producing a private key
Cryptography Q4: The file or message has not been tampered with during transit or storage
Cryptography Q5: The sender hashes the message or file to produce a message digest and applies the chosen decryption algorithm and their private key to it. This is the signature. The recipient uses the sender's public key and applies the corresponding encryption algorithm to the signature which will produce a matching message digest only if the message or file is authentically from the sender
Cryptography Q6: Government policies and actions mean that most cryptographic systems available to business are easily broken when government needs to for law enforcement or national security needs
Cryptography Q7: No matter what kind of cryptanalytic attack the larger the key the larger the possible space of key values that an attacker must test; each additional binary bit doubles this search or testing time. Ultimately this requires more computing power and storage than even the most well-funded governments can afford
Cryptography Q8: No because this would allow the plaintext to be decrypted from the hash rendering message digests and digital signatures unworkable
Cryptography Q9: By protecting data in transit (via Internet or other means) it protects data when en route between two or more physically separated points (in space)Since much of the Internet is carried on long-haul backbone circuits that go via satellite encryption is used to protect data while being transmitted via radio through space to and from the satellite and ground stations. Without encryption anybody could receive these signals and break out the data being exchangedDespite traveling at the speed of light Internet traffic takes time to go from one user's system to another (i.e. from a client to a server); thus encryption protects the data in motion during this timeEncrypting a file for storage ensures that it cannot be read or tampered with by unauthorized users or processes (which do not have the key); later authorized users with the key can read the file
Cryptography Q10: Display of data to humans or output of data as device commands in control systems needs to be in an unecrypted for to be usableEven cryptographic support for nonrepudiation cannot prove that a recipient (authorized of not) actually read and understood or made use of the contents of a protected file or message; it can only prove that they accessed itUsers with legitimate access to a variety of information at one level of classification when decrypted for use may be able to infer the existence or value of information at higher levels of classification
BCDR Q1: Using off-site systems and data archives
BCDR Q2: RTO should exceed MAO
BCDR Q4: Planning is more important than the plans it produces
BCDR Q7: We have to comply with our policies that tell us how to handle incidents like this and so we can't do thatYours are not the only systems affected by this attack; we've had to shut down most of our IT operations to make sure that our critical data and systems are protected
BCDR Q8: Indicators are events that are part of an information security incident kill chain; warnings are observable effects that we can detect that tell us of the occurrences of the indicator
BCDR Q9: Malware quarantine operations are an example of containment and eradication achieved with the same task
BCDR Q10: Recurrent problems with data corruption in database entries

Cryptography Q2: Was used extensively in classical encryption but has since been superseded by much stronger asymmetric encryption
Cryptography Q3: Hashing is one-way cryptography in that you transform a meaningful plaintext into a meaningless but unique hash value but you cannot go from hash value back to the original meaning or plaintext
Cryptography Q4: The file or message has not been viewed by others or copied without the sender's and named recipient's knowledge
Cryptography Q5: The sender hashes the message or file to produce a message digest and applies the chosen decryption algorithm and their private key to it. This is the signature. The recipient uses the sender's public key and applies the corresponding encryption algorithm to the signature which will produce a matching message digest only if the message or file is authentically from the sender
Cryptography Q6: In many jurisdictions law and regulation place significant responsibilities for information protection and due diligence on businesses; these can only be met in practical ways by using cryptographic systems
Cryptography Q7: This is only a concern for block ciphers since if the key size is too small these ciphers are easily broken with rainbow table or dictionary attacks
Cryptography Q8: In a limited way they are reversible because the hash acts as a pointer or key into database and file management systems where the plaintext comes from
Cryptography Q9: Despite traveling at the speed of light Internet traffic takes time to go from one user's system to another (i.e. from a client to a server); thus encryption protects the data in motion during this time
Cryptography Q10: Cryptography cannot be used to reduce risks to information availability

Cryptography Q1: Obscuring meaning by misdirection concealment or deception
Cryptography Q2: Uses the same key or a simple transform of it to encrypt plaintext into ciphertext and to then decrypt the ciphertext back into plaintext
Cryptography Q3: Hashing is almost exclusively used to produce indexes and pointers for database and file systems
Cryptography Q4: The file or message has not been viewed by others or copied without the sender's and named recipient's knowledge
Cryptography Q5: The sender encrypts the message or file with their private key and hashes the encrypted file to produce the signed message digest. This is the signature. The recipient uses the sender's public key and applies the corresponding decryption algorithm tot he signature which will produce a matching message digest only if the message or file is authentically from the sender

Ultimately this requires more computing power and storage than even the most well-funded governments can afford

Cryptography Q9: Since much of the Internet is carried on long-haul backbone circuits that go via satellite encryption is used to protect data while being transmitted via radio through space to and from the satellite and ground stations. Without encryption anybody could receive these signals and break out the data being exchangedEncrypting a file for storage ensures that it cannot be read or tampered with by unauthorized users or processes (which do not have the key); later authorized users with the key can read the file

Cryptography Q1: Digitally signing files and messages to authenticate senders
Cryptography Q2: Uses the same key or a simple transform of it to encrypt plaintext into ciphertext and to then decrypt the ciphertext back into plaintext
Cryptography Q3: Hashing is one-way cryptography in that you transform a meaningful plaintext into a meaningless but unique hash value but you cannot go from hash value back to the original meaning or plaintext
Cryptography Q4: The certificate public key or both associated with the sender or author match what is associated with the file or message
Cryptography Q5: The sender hashes the message or file to produce a message digest and applies the chosen decryption algorithm and their private key to it. This is the signature. The recipient uses the sender's public key and applies the corresponding encryption algorithm to the signature which will produce a matching message digest only if the message or file is authentically from the sender
Cryptography Q6: In many jurisdictions law and regulation place significant responsibilities for information protection and due diligence on businesses; these can only be met in practical ways by using cryptographic systems
Cryptography Q7: No matter what kind of cryptanalytic attack the larger the key the larger the possible space of key values that an attacker must test; each additional binary bit doubles this search or testing time. Ultimately this requires more computing power and storage than even the most well-funded governments can afford
Cryptography Q8: No because this would allow the plaintext to be decrypted from the hash rendering message digests and digital signatures unworkable
